text: When a memory or flashback appears, I notice it as a past event and breathe to stay grounded in the present.
During moments when I feel triggered, I pause and recognize that the danger is in the past, not happening now.
When my body reacts with tension or alertness, I notice the response and choose to breathe and ground myself.
I let intrusive memories or flashbacks feel like they are happening again in the present moment.
When I notice myself scanning for danger or threats, I recognize it as hypervigilance and choose to relax my attention.
I see when my mind is replaying traumatic events, and I choose to redirect my focus to the present moment.
When I feel the urge to avoid places or situations, I notice the fear and choose to face it gradually instead.
I let emotional numbness or disconnection from others control my relationships and daily life.
When I notice negative thoughts about myself or the trauma, I recognize them as patterns and choose self-compassion instead.
I recognize when my body is in survival mode, and I use grounding techniques to bring myself back to safety.
When I feel irritable or angry without a clear reason, I notice it as a trauma response and choose to pause before reacting.
I let nightmares or disturbing dreams about the trauma disrupt my sleep and affect my daily functioning.
When I sense reminders or triggers approaching, I prepare my breathing and grounding techniques ahead of time.
I see when my mind is stuck in the past, and I choose to anchor myself in the present moment instead.
When I feel the pull to isolate or disconnect, I notice the pattern and choose to reach out or stay connected instead.
I let fear of triggers or reminders prevent me from engaging in activities or going to places I used to enjoy.
When I notice my startle response or hypervigilance activating, I breathe and remind myself that I am safe now.
I recognize when guilt or shame about the trauma appears, and I choose to treat myself with kindness instead.
When I feel the cycle of trauma reactions starting, I interrupt it early by grounding myself and staying present.
I let trauma responses control my behavior and make me feel like I am still in danger even when I am safe.
